contains.display: DCIS nuclear pleomorphism, grade 1: monotonous nuclei, 1.5 - 2.0 RBC diameters, with finely dispersed chromatin and only occasional nucleoli
DCIS nuclear pleomorphism, grade 2: neither nuclear grade 1 nor nuclear grade 3
DCIS nuclear pleomorphism, grade 3: Markedly pleomorphic nuclei, usually >2.5 RBC diameters, with coarse chromatin and multiple nucleoli
Differentiating neuroblastoma
FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) grading system grade 1
FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) grading system grade 2
FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) grading system grade 3
Fuhrman nuclear grade finding
G1 grade
G1: 5 percent or less non-squamous solid growth
G1: Nuclei round, uniform, approximately 10 µ; nucleoli inconspicuous or absent
G1: Well differentiated
G1: Well differentiated (greater than 95 percent gland forming)
G1: Well differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasm
G1: Well differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasm, typical carcinoid of thorax
G2 grade
G2: 6-50 percent non-squamous solid growth
G2: Moderately differentiated
G2: Moderately differentiated (50-95 percent gland forming)
G2: Nuclei slightly irregular, approximately 15 µ; nucleoli evident
G2: Well differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasm
G2: Well differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasm, atypical carcinoid of thorax
G3 grade
G3: More than 50 percent non-squamous solid growth
G3: Nuclei very irregular, approximately 20 µ; nucleoli large and prominent
G3: Poorly differentiated
G3: Poorly differentiated (5-49 percent gland forming)
G3: Well differentiated neuroendocrine neoplasm
G4 grade
G4: Nuclei bizarre and multilobated, 20 µ or greater, nucleoli prominent, chromatin clumped
G4: Undifferentiated
G4: Undifferentiated (less than 5 percent gland forming)
GB: Borderline tumour

GX: Histologic grade cannot be assessed
GX: Neuroendocrine neoplasm grade cannot be assessed
